Patient History.Initial Event: In 1989, a 21-year-old male experienced visual loss after diving from a diving board.
Patient History.Initial Examination: Ocular examination revealed bilateral subretinal hemorrhages and angioid streaks.
Patient History.Follow-up: After clearing of the hemorrhages, more breaks of Bruch’s membrane were identified. The macula was not affected and vision returned to normal in both eyes.

April 2009.Findings: Active choroidal neovascularisation nasal to the fovea with leakage and edema.
April 2009.Diagnosis: Tentative diagnosis of PXE with angioid streaks, peau d’orange, and a few comet tails observed.

Treatment.Initial Treatment: One month after a first intravitreal injection of bevacizumab, the edema had resolved and vision improved.
Treatment.Follow-up Treatment: A total of 8 injections of bevacizumab were administered on the left eye, but growth of the choroidal neovascularization was observed with further deterioration of vision.

January 2010.Right Eye: Active CNV identified and treatment with bevacizumab intravitreal injections was initiated.

Findings.Left Eye: Large subfoveal CNV expanding on both sides of the fovea.
Findings.Right Eye: Smaller and mildly active subfoveal CNV requiring further treatment.

Diagnostic Tests.Dermatologic Examination: No typical plucked-chicken appearance, no papules, macules or other skin lesions.
Diagnostic Tests.Biopsies: Three biopsies from the flexural skin of the axilla and the neck did not reveal PXE related changes.
Diagnostic Tests.Genetic Analysis: Patient was homozygous for the R1141X-mutation in the ABCC6-gene.

Final Diagnosis: The diagnosis of PXE was withheld, discussed with the patient, and shared with his treating generalist.
